item.title: Radish
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Radish

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Radishes are incredibly quick and easy to grow. These sharp-tasting little root-veggies are perfect for a first-time farmer. They’ll tolerate a wide variety of conditions and do really well in containers. There are a range of varieties available, so choose your favourite, or try a few.

Classic mistakes:
Don’t let the soil become too dry. If the soil dries out, radishes may crack or go to seed before you have a chance to harvest them.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Full Sun

Soil preparation:
Radishes like rich, well-draining soil. Add some compost to your soil before you plant.

Grow radishes in full sun or partial shade. Plant radishes in loose, well-drained soil. Remove soil lumps, rocks, and roots from radish planting beds. Obstructions can cause roots to grow malformed. Add organic matter to planting beds before sowing radishes. Radishes prefer a soil pH of 5.5 to 6.8.

Radishes do best on sandy, well-drained soils. This allows for even root development and ease of washing after harvest. Lime the soil if the pH is below 5.5 (water system of measurement). Deeper soils are required for the production of good quality long white radish.

Sow seed: All Year RoundSowing depth: 6mm Radishes can be planted year-round; however, you may find that they bolt too seed quickly in the hot, summer months. Sprinkle the seeds over your soil and cover lightly with soil or compost and water well. Sow seed every 2 weeks for an almost constant supply of radishes. Avoid planting seedlings.

Once your seedlings are up, thin them out according to the instructions on the seed packaging.

Watering:
The soil should be moist and well-drained. Water your radishes regularly to prevent them from cracking, but don’t let them sit in wet soil.

Feeding:
Don’t overfeed your radishes, too much nitrogen will result in beautiful leaves and underdeveloped roots. They grow so quickly that feeding may not be necessary, but if you do feed them, be sure to use a low nitrogen feed like compost tea.

Mulching:
Radishes will appreciate a good organic mulch to keep the weeds out and the soil moist. Good options are lucerne, pea straw or sugar cane.

Harvest: 4 to 7 Weeks After Planting

Simply pull your radishes from the soil. Try to harvest them while they’re still young. If they stay in the ground for too long, they start to become hard. The greens can be harvested at any stage and used in salads.

Radishes are incredibly quick and easy to grow. These sharp-tasting little root-veggies are perfect for a first-time farmer. They\u2019ll tolerate a wide variety of conditions and do really well in containers. There are a range of varieties available, so choose your favourite, or try a few.<\/p>

Classic mistakes:<\/strong>
Don\u2019t let the soil become too dry. If the soil dries out, radishes may crack or go to seed before you have a chance to harvest them.<\/p>

Sunlight:<\/strong>
Grow in: Full Sun<\/p>

Soil preparation:<\/strong>
Radishes like rich, well-draining soil. Add some compost to your soil before you plant.<\/p>"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Growing environment","_id":"8b31748","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Grow radishes in full sun or partial shade. Plant radishes in loose, well-drained soil. Remove soil lumps, rocks, and roots from radish planting beds. Obstructions can cause roots to grow malformed. Add organic matter to planting beds before sowing radishes. Radishes prefer a soil pH of 5.5 to 6.8.<\/p>

Radishes do best on sandy, well-drained soils. This allows for even root development and ease of washing after harvest. Lime the soil if the pH is below 5.5 (water system of measurement). item.title: Eggplant
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Eggplant

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Eggplants are known by many names and various varieties have been cultivated in vast regions of the globe. They come in a variety of shapes and sizes and are attractive bushes which make a stunning addition to any vegetable garden. They love the heat, so they thrive in the Victorian summers and are reasonably drought tolerant. Plant them in a sunny spot and they’ll reward you with an abundant harvest all summer long.

Classic mistakes:
Eggplants need their space. If you follow square foot gardening or companion planting methods, be sure to give them enough space to grow. They don’t want to be shaded or compete for nutrients.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Full Sun

Eggplants need full sun. Plant them in the sunniest spot you can.

Soil preparation:
Eggplants are heavy feeders. Be sure to work some compost and well-rotted manure into your soil before planting. Remember not to plant where tomatoes, peppers, eggplants or potatoes have grown the previous year.

Eggplants are heavy feeders. Be sure to work some compost and well-rotted manure into your soil before planting. Remember not to plant where tomatoes, peppers, eggplants or potatoes have grown the previous year.

Sow seed: August-SeptemberSowing depth: 5-10mm 

Soak seeds in water overnight.

Eggplants need really warm soil to germinate. You can start them in the garden once the soil is warm, but its easiest to start them indoors, preferably on a heat mat. Simply cover the seeds with soil and keep them warm and moist. If you want to get a head start on the growing season, then its quicker and easier to plant seedlings.

Plant seedlings: October-January 

Plant seedlings at least 50cm apart and stake for support. The bushes can grow quite large and they need a bit of extra support to protect them in windy weather. Stakes or cages are both good options for support. It’s also a good idea to add some bonemeal to your planting holes. They like the extra calcium in the bonemeal and it helps them to produce a strong root system.

Pinch out the growing tips for a bushier plant and limit fruits to 5 or 6 per plant for better a size and quality of fruit.

Watering:
The hot, dry Victorian summers cause the ground to dry out very quickly. Make sure your eggplants get watered regularly, but don’t let the soil get soggy or water logged. They can handle the soil drying out, but will really struggle in waterlogged soil..

Feeding:
If your soil was well prepared, then your eggplants shouldn’t need feeding again until the flowers appear. As soon as they start to flower, give them a low-nitrogen feed to encourage flowers and fruit. Compost tea, a balanced organic fertiliser or a tomato fertiliser are all good options. Feed every 3 or 4 weeks through the fruiting season.

Mulching:
A thick layer of organic mulch helps to stop water from evaporating in the hot, dry, Victorian summers. Lucerne, pea straw or sugarcane are all great, organic options. The mulch will break down and add organic matter to your soil over time, so keep topping it up throughout the growing the season.

Harvest: 10 to 15 Weeks After Planting

You can pick the fruit at any stage, depending on your requirements. As soon as the fruits reach the size you would like, use a sharp knife or secateurs to cut the fruit from the plant. The fruits should be firm and glossy. If they start looking dull, they’re past their best. They can still be eaten, but will be slightly more bitter and spongy.

item.title: Corn
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Corn

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Corn is one of those veggies that just tastes so much better if you grow it yourself! You need a fair amount of space to grow corn, because it’s wind pollinated so you need a decent amount of plants to get a high enough pollination rate. It’s a warm season crop which originates in South America and thrives in the hot, dry Victorian summers. Supermarkets usually stock sweet corn, while other varieties are grown and dried for maizemeal and popcorn. The maize-meal varieties can also be eaten fresh, but they aren’t as sweet as sweet corn. They are still pretty delicious and definitely worth a try for the more adventurous eaters.

Classic mistake:
Make sure to plant enough corn plants, 12 plants is probably the smallest you can go, but the fertilisation rates will be much better if you have space for 40 – 80 plants. If you plan to save your seeds for next year, you’ll need to have at least 40 plants to maintain genetic variety.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Partial Sun - Full Sun

Soil preparation:
Corn is a particularly heavy feeder. Add lots of compost and well-rotted manure to your soil before planting and dig it through well. Then add some blood and bone, rake it through, water well and let it sit for a week before planting.

Corn is a particularly heavy feeder. Add lots of compost and well-rotted manure to your soil before planting and dig it through well. Then add some blood and bone, rake it through, water well and let it sit for a week before planting.

Sow seed: September-DecemberSowing depth: 5 - 7 mm

Sow your corn once its consistently warm and all danger of frost has passed.

The minimum size for a corn bed is 4 plants by 3 plants. Sow your seeds according to the directions on the packaging. Sow 2 seeds per hole and then thin them out once they're up and established. The thinned plants can be used to fill in any gaps in the bed if germination rates are low. As a fun experiment, you could try the 3 sisters companion planting combination to make the most of the space needed for your corn.

Plant seedlings: September-January

Plant your seedlings out once its consistently warm and all danger of frost has passed.

Corn grows well from seedlings. Plant them into a well-prepared bed, water in and mulch well. Adding a small amount of organic bone meal to each hole will help your corn to develop a strong root system, which will get them through the hot dry weather and produce strong plants.

Corn is wind pollinated, so if your corn patch is on the small side (most urban gardens are), you’ll need to help a bit with pollination. There are various techniques, but an easy and effective way is to use brown paper bags. Keep an eye on the tassels (the male flower right on top of the stalk). Once the tassels turn yellow and start to produce pollen granules, place a bag over them and give them a good shake to collect the pollen. Then, using a paint brush, dust pollen over the female silks found lower on the plant. Repeat this every day for a week for best results. Always remember to wait until the dew on the pollen has dried before you collect it. Pollen doesn’t keep well, so collect a fresh batch each day. If that sounds a bit too labour intensive, you can just pick some tassels each day and dust the silk with them.

Your corn plants may develop side shoots called suckers. In earlier years it was thought that suckers should be removed, but these days its widely accepted that its better not to remove them. Breaking them off creates wounds which can allow diseases to enter the plant. Suckers have no detrimental affect on the main stalk and larger suckers may even help provide the main stalk with nutrients. If you want to break them off, try to do it while the suckers are still small, so that it has less of an effect on the main stalk.

Watering:
Corn is a thirsty plant and needs lots of water, especially towards the end of the growing season when the cobs are swelling. The only time you shouldn’t over-water is when you plant your seeds. The seeds can rot easily in the ground, so give them a good soaking when you plant and then wait until they emerge to water again.

Feeding:
Corn is a heavy feeder. Start with a well-prepared bed and then feed again when the flowers appear. A nitrogen-rich feed like manure tea is ideal. Mound compost around your stalks to provide them extra nutrients.

Mulching:
A good thick mulch will make growing corn so much easier! It helps to smother the weeds and keep water in. Lucerne, sugar-cane or pea straw are all good options, but feel free to just use what you have on hand.

Harvest: 10 to 12 Weeks After Planting

When the silks start to die and turn brown, your corn is probably ripe. Stick your nail into one of the kernels, if the liquid that comes out is clear, leave them a little longer. If its milky, its time to harvest.

Simply pull the cobs down till they snap away from the stalks. Heirloom sweetcorn varieties need to be eaten almost immediately. The newer, super sweet varieties can be stored for up to a week before their quality starts to deteriorate.

[{"id":"3d729a1","elType":"section","settings":{"height":"min-height","background_background":"classic","background_image":{"url":"http:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/corn.jpg","id":353},"background_position":"center center","background_size":"cover","background_overlay_background":"classic","background_overlay_color":"#000000"},"elements":[{"id":"c4412f0","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"b33809f","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Corn","align":"center","title_color":"#FFFFFF","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Roboto","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"600"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d5f6a4f","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_image":{"url":"http:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/field_background.jpg","id":1152},"background_position":"bottom center","background_size":"cover","background_overlay_background":"classic","background_overlay_color":"#FFFFFF","background_overlay_opacity":{"unit":"px","size":0.6,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"9d9cf66","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"2100a4d","elType":"widget","settings":{"eael_adv_tab_layout":"eael-tabs-vertical","eael_adv_tabs_icon_show":"","eael_adv_tabs_tab":[{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Overview","_id":"bf593e9","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Corn is one of those veggies that just tastes so much better if you grow it yourself! You need a fair amount of space to grow corn, because it\u2019s wind pollinated so you need a decent amount of plants to get a high enough pollination rate. It\u2019s a warm season crop which originates in South America and thrives in the hot, dry Victorian summers. Supermarkets usually stock sweet corn, while other varieties are grown and dried for maizemeal and popcorn. The maize-meal varieties can also be eaten fresh, but they aren\u2019t as sweet as sweet corn. They are still pretty delicious and definitely worth a try for the more adventurous eaters.<\/p>

Classic mistake:<\/strong>
Make sure to plant enough corn plants, 12 plants is probably the smallest you can go, but the fertilisation rates will be much better if you have space for 40 \u2013 80 plants. If you plan to save your seeds for next year, you\u2019ll need to have at least 40 plants to maintain genetic variety.<\/span><\/p>

Sunlight:<\/strong>
Grow in: Partial Sun - Full Sun<\/p>

Soil preparation:<\/strong>
Corn is a particularly heavy feeder. Add lots of compost and well-rotted manure to your soil before planting and dig it through well. Then add some blood and bone, rake it through, water well and let it sit for a week before planting.<\/p>"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Growing environment","_id":"8b31748","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Corn is a particularly heavy feeder. Add lots of compost and well-rotted manure to your soil before planting and dig it through well. Then add some blood and bone, rake it through, water well and let it sit for a week before planting.<\/p>"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Sowing seed","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Sow seed: September-December<\/strong><\/div>
Sowing depth: 5 - 7 mm<\/strong><\/div>

Sow your corn once its consistently warm and all danger of frost has passed.<\/p><\/div>

The minimum size for a corn bed is 4 plants by 3 plants. Sow your seeds according to the directions on the packaging. Sow 2 seeds per hole and then thin them out once they're up and established. The thinned plants can be used to fill in any gaps in the bed if germination rates are low. As a fun experiment, you could try the 3 sisters companion planting combination to make the most of the space needed for your corn.<\/p><\/div>","_id":"537c85d"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Planting","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Plant seedlings: September-January<\/strong><\/div>

Plant your seedlings out once its consistently warm and all danger of frost has passed.<\/p><\/div>

Corn grows well from seedlings. Plant them into a well-prepared bed, water in and mulch well. Adding a small amount of organic bone meal to each hole will help your corn to develop a strong root system, which will get them through the hot dry weather and produce strong plants.<\/p><\/div><\/div>","_id":"4d21632"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Care","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Corn is wind pollinated, so if your corn patch is on the small side (most urban gardens are), you\u2019ll need to help a bit with pollination. There are various techniques, but an easy and effective way is to use brown paper bags. Keep an eye on the tassels (the male flower right on top of the stalk). Once the tassels turn yellow and start to produce pollen granules, place a bag over them and give them a good shake to collect the pollen. Then, using a paint brush, dust pollen over the female silks found lower on the plant. Repeat this every day for a week for best results. Always remember to wait until the dew on the pollen has dried before you collect it. Pollen doesn\u2019t keep well, so collect a fresh batch each day. If that sounds a bit too labour intensive, you can just pick some tassels each day and dust the silk with them.<\/p>

Your corn plants may develop side shoots called suckers. In earlier years it was thought that suckers should be removed, but these days its widely accepted that its better not to remove them. Breaking them off creates wounds which can allow diseases to enter the plant. Suckers have no detrimental affect on the main stalk and larger suckers may even help provide the main stalk with nutrients. If you want to break them off, try to do it while the suckers are still small, so that it has less of an effect on the main stalk.<\/p>

Watering:<\/strong>
Corn is a thirsty plant and needs lots of water, especially towards the end of the growing season when the cobs are swelling. The only time you shouldn\u2019t over-water is when you plant your seeds. The seeds can rot easily in the ground, so give them a good soaking when you plant and then wait until they emerge to water again.<\/p>

Feeding:<\/strong>
Corn is a heavy feeder. Start with a well-prepared bed and then feed again when the flowers appear. A nitrogen-rich feed like manure tea is ideal. Mound compost around your stalks to provide them extra nutrients.<\/p>

Mulching:<\/strong>
A good thick mulch will make growing corn so much easier! It helps to smother the weeds and keep water in. Lucerne, sugar-cane or pea straw are all good options, but feel free to just use what you have on hand.<\/p><\/div><\/div>","_id":"720f837"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Harvesting","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Harvest: 10 to 12 Weeks After Planting<\/strong><\/div>

When the silks start to die and turn brown, your corn is probably ripe. Stick your nail into one of the kernels, if the liquid that comes out is clear, leave them a little longer. If its milky, its time to harvest.<\/p>

Simply pull the cobs down till they snap away from the stalks. Heirloom sweetcorn varieties need to be eaten almost immediately. The newer, super sweet varieties can be stored for up to a week before their quality starts to deteriorate.<\/p><\/div><\/div>

\u00a0<\/div><\/div><\/div><\/div><\/div>","_id":"3f2d661"}],"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_typography":"custom","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_weight":"600","eael_adv_tabs_tab_text_color":"","eael_adv_tabs_tab_color_hover":"#54BC32","eael_adv_tabs_tab_color_active":"#54BC32","adv_tabs_content_text_color":"#000F2B","eael_adv_tabs_content_typography_typography":"custom","eael_adv_tabs_content_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","eael_adv_tabs_tab_caret_color":"#54BC32"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"eael-adv-tabs"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Celery
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Celery

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Celery is a cool season crop and is best grown in the moderate weather of spring to early summer. It has a reputation of being hard to grow, but when planted in the right conditions, it can thrive in the farm.

Classic mistakes:
Don’t plant celery when the weather is too warm or too cold. The key to success with celery is moderate weather.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Partial Shade - Full Sun

You might be tempted to plant celery in a shady spot because it’s a leafy green. Celery actually needs quite a lot of sun to produce big plants and long stems. It needs at least 5-7 hours of sun a day, but will enjoy some afternoon shade.

Soil preparation:
Dig in lots compost and well-rotted manure. Celery is a heavy feeder and likes rich, well-draining soil. Celery plants have exceptionally fine roots, so they need very light soil. If you have heavier soil in your garden, then you can plant them into pure compost in a raised bed.

You might be tempted to plant celery in a shady environment because it’s a leafy green. Celery actually needs quite a lot of sun to produce big plants and long stems. It needs at least 5-7 hours of sun a day, but will enjoy some afternoon shade.

Dig in lots compost and well-rotted manure. Celery is a heavy feeder and likes rich, well-draining soil. Celery plants have exceptionally fine roots, so they need very light soil. If you have heavier soil in your field, then you can plant them into pure compost in a raised bed.

Sow seed: September-OctoberSowing depth: Simply sprinkle the seeds onto your soil, cover loosely, and water in. 

Soak the seeds for 24 hours before planting.

Simply sprinkle the seeds onto your soil, cover loosely, and water in. Celery is quite tricky to grow from seed, so unless you’re a very experienced gardener, rather plant seedlings. Celery seeds are really tiny, which makes them hard to sow evenly. Like carrots, they need to be thinned once they’re up. The easiest way to thin them is to use a small pair of scissors and simply cut away the unwanted seedlings. Cutting is a great way to remove any extra seedlings without disturbing the ones you plan to keep.

Plant seedlings: November-December 

Plant celery in trenches and gradually full the trenches as the celery grows, this helps to blanch the stems and makes them tastier when eaten raw. Celery doesn’t like to be crowded, so make sure there is only one plant per hole. Sometimes even bought seedling may contain more than one plant per pot. If this is the case, either separate them and plant both or thin the weaker plant. Celery can also be grown from discarded celery roots. Simply buy celery that still has its roots on, use the stalks, and re-root the roots; either in soil or water.

Once the stalks reach a good size, tie them loosely and then wrap them in newspaper. Allow the leaves to sick out the top. You can harvest them 2-3 weeks later. The newspaper will protect them from the sun, and they should be pale when you harvest them.

Watering:
Water regularly to keep the soil moist. Celery likes moist soil, so don’t let it dry out. Remember to give your plants extra water during hot, dry weather.

Feeding:
Celery is a very heavy feeder. Give your plants a good, nitrogen-rich feed every few weeks. Manure, compost tea or organic fertiliser are all good options.

Mulching:
Mulch your celery plants with a thick layer of organic mulch. This will help to keep their roots cool and moist. Lucerne, sugarcane and pea-straw are all good options.

Harvest: 11 to 18 Weeks After Planting

Celery can be harvested whole or you may remove one stalk at a time as needed. Simply pull the tops of the stalks down towards the soil to snap them off the plant or cut them at the base as you would for spinach.

item.title: Zucchini
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Zucchini

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

A quick and easy-to-grow little squash. Zucchinis start to bear very quickly and if they’re happy, they’ll produce an abundance of versatile veggies for the kitchen. They do well in the hot, dry Victorian summers and produce a lot of food quickly and in a relatively small space.

Classic mistakes:
Water your zucchinis regularly. Infrequent watering stresses the plants and causes all sorts of problems.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Full Sun

Zucchinis need a good amount of sun, but like most veggies, will be happy with some afternoon shade.

Soil preparation:
Zucchinis love rich, moist soil. Dig plenty of compost and well-rotted manure into your soil. Soil with a high organic content will hold more moisture, which these squash really like.

Zucchinis need a good amount of sun, but like most veggies, will be happy with some afternoon shade.

Zucchinis love rich, moist soil. Dig plenty of compost and well-rotted manure into your soil. Soil with a high organic content will hold more moisture, which these squash really like.

Sow seed: September-JanuarySowing depth: 20 mm

Sow zucchinis into the garden once all danger of frost has passed and its consistently warm. They are very sensitive to frost and thrive in hot weather, so they’re not worth starting until its properly warm.

Zucchinis can be planted as seedlings, but are best planted from seed. Keep them moist until they are established and follow the spacing suggestions on the seed packaging. Zucchini plants can grow quite big and need a fair amount of space.

Plant seedlings: September-February

Plant your zucchinis out into the field once all danger of frost has passed and its consistently warm. They are very sensitive to frost and thrive in hot weather.

Handle your seedlings gently, taking care not to damage their delicate roots. Place a small amount of bonemeal into each hole before planting. It’ll help your seedling to develop strong root systems which leads to healthy, vigorous plant. Water them well and don’t let the soil dry out while they’re settling in.

If your fruits start to shrink and rot while they’re still small, its probably because they haven’t been properly pollinated. Luckily this problem is easily solved through hand pollination.

As the plant grows, remove any older leaves that are diseased, damaged or yellowing. This will help the plant to direct more energy towards new growth and fruit, instead or supporting old, damaged leaves.

Watering:
Zucchinis love water. Be sure to keep the soil moist, and, if possible, do not water their leaves. They’re particularly prone to fungal diseases (like powdery mildew) so of you must water the leaves, do so in the morning, so that the plants can dry during the heat of the day.

Feeding:
Feed every 4 weeks with a balanced organic fertiliser.

Mulching:
Give them a good thick layer of organic mulch to keep the soil moist and the weeds out. Zucchinis have a relatively shallow root system, so a thick layer of mulch will also help to keep the roots cool. Lucerne or sugarcane are good options.

Harvest: 6 to 9 Weeks After Planting

When the zucchinis reach the desired size, simply twist the fruit off or use a sharp knife to cut them away from the vine. Picking the zucchinis will encourage the plant to keep producing fruit. Zucchinis can be left on the vine and grow bigger rapidly, but the bigger they are, the more watery and less flavourful they become.

[{"id":"63c9245","elType":"section","settings":{"layout":"full_width","height":"min-height","background_background":"classic","background_image":{"url":"http:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/zucchini2.jpg","id":366},"background_overlay_background":"classic","background_overlay_color":"#000000","background_size":"cover","background_position":"center center"},"elements":[{"id":"c4876d0","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"825e1a4","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Zucchini","align":"center","title_color":"#FFFFFF","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Roboto","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":40,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"600"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"0f28858","elType":"section","settings":{"background_background":"classic","background_image":{"url":"http:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/10\/field_background.jpg","id":1152},"background_position":"bottom center","background_size":"cover","background_overlay_background":"classic","background_overlay_color":"#FFFFFF","background_overlay_opacity":{"unit":"px","size":0.6,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"a3a23bc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5d2743e","elType":"widget","settings":{"eael_adv_tab_layout":"eael-tabs-vertical","eael_adv_tabs_icon_show":"","eael_adv_tabs_tab":[{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Overview","_id":"bf593e9","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

A quick and easy-to-grow little squash. Zucchinis start to bear very quickly and if they\u2019re happy, they\u2019ll produce an abundance of versatile veggies for the kitchen. They do well in the hot, dry Victorian summers and produce a lot of food quickly and in a relatively small space.<\/p>

Classic mistakes:<\/strong>
Water your zucchinis regularly. Infrequent watering stresses the plants and causes all sorts of problems.<\/span><\/p>

Sunlight:<\/strong>
Grow in: Full Sun<\/p>

Zucchinis need a good amount of sun, but like most veggies, will be happy with some afternoon shade.<\/p>

Soil preparation:<\/strong>
Zucchinis love rich, moist soil. Dig plenty of compost and well-rotted manure into your soil. Soil with a high organic content will hold more moisture, which these squash really like.<\/p><\/div>"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Growing environment","_id":"8b31748","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Zucchinis need a good amount of sun, but like most veggies, will be happy with some afternoon shade.<\/p>

Zucchinis love rich, moist soil. Dig plenty of compost and well-rotted manure into your soil. Soil with a high organic content will hold more moisture, which these squash really like.<\/p>"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Sowing seed","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Sow seed: September-January<\/strong><\/div>
Sowing depth: 20 mm<\/strong><\/div>

Sow zucchinis into the garden once all danger of frost has passed and its consistently warm. They are very sensitive to frost and thrive in hot weather, so they\u2019re not worth starting until its properly warm.<\/p><\/div>

Zucchinis can be planted as seedlings, but are best planted from seed. Keep them moist until they are established and follow the spacing suggestions on the seed packaging. Zucchini plants can grow quite big and need a fair amount of space.<\/p><\/div><\/div>","_id":"537c85d"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Planting","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Plant seedlings: September-February<\/strong><\/div>

Plant your zucchinis out into the field once all danger of frost has passed and its consistently warm. They are very sensitive to frost and thrive in hot weather.<\/p><\/div>

Handle your seedlings gently, taking care not to damage their delicate roots. Place a small amount of bonemeal into each hole before planting. It\u2019ll help your seedling to develop strong root systems which leads to healthy, vigorous plant. Water them well and don\u2019t let the soil dry out while they\u2019re settling in.<\/p><\/div><\/div>","_id":"4d21632"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Care","eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

If your fruits start to shrink and rot while they\u2019re still small, its probably because they haven\u2019t been properly pollinated. Luckily this problem is easily solved through hand pollination.<\/p>

As the plant grows, remove any older leaves that are diseased, damaged or yellowing. This will help the plant to direct more energy towards new growth and fruit, instead or supporting old, damaged leaves.<\/p>

Watering:<\/strong>
Zucchinis love water. Be sure to keep the soil moist, and, if possible, do not water their leaves. They\u2019re particularly prone to fungal diseases (like powdery mildew) so of you must water the leaves, do so in the morning, so that the plants can dry during the heat of the day.<\/p>

Feeding:<\/strong>
Feed every 4 weeks with a balanced organic fertiliser.<\/p>

Mulching:<\/strong>
Give them a good thick layer of organic mulch to keep the soil moist and the weeds out. Zucchinis have a relatively shallow root system, so a thick layer of mulch will also help to keep the roots cool. Lucerne or sugarcane are good options.<\/p><\/div><\/div>","_id":"720f837"},{"eael_adv_tabs_tab_show_as_default":"inactive","eael_adv_tabs_icon_type":"icon","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_icon_new":{"value":"fas fa-home","library":"fa-solid"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_image":{"url":"https:\/\/www.cropsomatic.ml\/wp-content\/plugins\/exclusive-addons-for-elementor\/assets\/img\/placeholder.png"},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title":"Harvesting","eael_adv_tabs_text_type":"content","eael_adv_tabs_tab_content":"

Harvest: 6 to 9 Weeks After Planting<\/strong><\/div>

When the zucchinis reach the desired size, simply twist the fruit off or use a sharp knife to cut them away from the vine. Picking the zucchinis will encourage the plant to keep producing fruit. Zucchinis can be left on the vine and grow bigger rapidly, but the bigger they are, the more watery and less flavourful they become.<\/p><\/div><\/div>

\u00a0<\/div><\/div><\/div><\/div><\/div>","_id":"3f2d661"}],"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_typography":"custom","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":20,"sizes":[]},"eael_adv_tabs_tab_title_typography_font_weight":"600","eael_adv_tabs_tab_text_color":"","eael_adv_tabs_tab_color_hover":"#54BC32","eael_adv_tabs_tab_color_active":"#54BC32","adv_tabs_content_text_color":"#000F2B","eael_adv_tabs_content_typography_typography":"custom","eael_adv_tabs_content_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","eael_adv_tabs_tab_caret_color":"#54BC32"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"eael-adv-tabs"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Carrot
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Carrot

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Carrots can be planted almost year-round in Victoria and are easy to grow. They take a while to mature and don’t like rich or heavy soil. Carrots do best in the cooler months and are sweetest when harvested after a frost.

Classic mistakes:
Carrots are all about soil. Don’t plant them in heavy soil or soil that contains many rocks. They’ll have stunted growth and strange shapes. If your soil is very heavy, rather plant carrots in raised beds or containers.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Full Sun

Carrots do best in full sun. They'll tolerate some shade during the hottest months; but in the cooler seasons, they need all the sun they can get.

Soil preparation:
Dig your soil through to loosen it nicely before you plant your carrots. Remove any stones and then rake the top layer so that it’s really fine. Carrots are a root crop, so don’t add anything that has a high nitrogen content. Too much nitrogen will give them lovely bushy leaves, but underdeveloped roots.

Carrots are all about soil. Don’t plant them in heavy soil or soil that contains many rocks. They’ll have stunted growth and strange shapes. If your soil is very heavy, rather plant carrots in raised beds or containers.

Carrots do best in full sun. They will tolerate some shade during the hottest months; but in the cooler seasons, they need all the sun they can get.

Dig your soil through to loosen it nicely before you plant your carrots. Remove any stones and then rake the top layer so that it’s really fine. Carrots are a root crop, so don’t add anything that has a high nitrogen content. Too much nitrogen will give them lovely bushy leaves, but underdeveloped roots.

Sow seed: September-MaySowing depth: 6mm

Sow every 6 weeks for a continuous harvest.

Make a trench 6 mm deep and gently sprinkle your seed into it. Cover loosely with soil and water well. Once the seedlings are up, thin them according the instructions on the packet. Carrot seed is very fine and difficult to sow evenly.

There are loads of tricks to make it easier. Some people mix their seeds with sand to get a more even spread.

Another good trick is to use a salt shaker to sprinkle the seeds.

Avoid planting seedlings.

Carrots are best planted from seeds.

Carrots need to be thinned twice. Thin them when they are about 5 cm high and again when they are about 12 cm high. The simplest way to thin them is to simply cut the unwanted plants off where they emerge from the soil. This kills the plant, but doesn’t disturb the roots of the plants around it. If you prefer, you can gently pull the unwanted plants from the soil, taking care not to disrupt the plants around them. It’s always a good idea to water your plants well after you thin them to help everything settle back down nicely.

Watering:
Keep your soil consistently damp. If the soil is too wet or too dry, your carrots can become cracked or misshapen.

Feeding:
Carrots don’t generally need too much extra feeding and definitely nothing with a high nitrogen content. You may feed them lightly every 6 weeks with a balanced organic fertiliser.

Mulching:
A good layer of organic mulch will help to keep your soil from drying out too quickly. Lucerne or sugar cane are good options. Remember, you should only mulch your plants once they are well established and a decent size.

Harvest: 12 to 18 Weeks After Planting

Gently pull your carrots from the soil when the reach the desired size. They can be harvested at any stage, depending on which size carrots you prefer. Smaller varieties will obviously mature quicker. The leaves can be added to your compost pile. Don’t leave your carrots in the soil for too long or they can start to become woody and lose their lovely sweet taste.

item.title: Homepage
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Are you worried about excessive rainfall for crops ?

Looking for ? Get Started

Know more about Gippsland

Gippsland is a rural region of Victoria, Australia, located in the south-eastern part of that state.

Gippsland is generally broken down into the East Gippsland, South Gippsland, West Gippsland, and the Latrobe Valley statistical divisions.

Read more

What we offer

Soil information

Weather information

Crop information

Recommendation

Support

About us

The CropSomatic project aims to provide recommendations to young farmers who are planning to start their career in farming.

Know more

DISCLAIMER

While we make effort to ensure that information and material on this site is accurate and up to date (unless denoted as archived materials), such materials and information do in no way constitute the provision of professional advice. CropSomatic does not guarantee, and accepts no legal liability whatsoever arising from or connected to, the accuracy, reliability, currency or completeness of any information and materials contained on this website or any linked sites.

Through this website, you will be able to see the links to the other websites which are not under the control of CropSomatic. We have no control over the nature, content and availability of those sites. The inclusion of any links does not necessarily imply a recommendation or endorse the views expressed within them.

item.title: Gippsland
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Gippsland

Climate issues in Gippsland, VIC

Temperature continue to increase year round

More hot days and warm spells

Less rainfall in winter and spring

More frequent and intense downpours

0 % Increase in the intensity of extreme rainfall estimated for each degree of warming 0 % Increase observed in the most extreme short‑duration rainfall extremes in Victoria

Overview of Gippsland

Gippsland value of agricultural production

In 2018–19, the gross value of agricultural production in the Latrobe-Gippsland region was $2.2 billion, which was 14 per cent of the total gross value of agricultural production in Victoria ($15.9billion). The most important commodities in the Latrobe-Gippsland region based on the gross value of agricultural production were milk ($926 million), followed by cattle and calves ($649 million) and sheep and lambs ($82 million). These commodities together contributed 76 per cent of the total value of agricultural production in the region. In 2018–19 the Latrobe-Gippsland region accounted for 91 per cent ($22 million) of the total value of Victoria’s green peas production.

Read moreClose

fa-angle-up","library":"fa-solid"},"custom_content":"

In 2018\u201319, the gross value of agricultural production in the Latrobe-Gippsland region was $2.2 billion, which was 14 per cent of the total gross value of agricultural production in Victoria ($15.9billion). The most important commodities in the Latrobe-Gippsland region based on the gross value of agricultural production were milk ($926 million), followed by cattle and calves ($649 million) and sheep and lambs ($82 million). These commodities together contributed 76 per cent of the total value of agricultural production in the region. In 2018\u201319 the Latrobe-Gippsland region accounted for 91 per cent ($22 million) of the total value of Victoria\u2019s green peas production.<\/p>","custom_content_color":"#625F5F","custom_content_typography_typography":"custom","custom_content_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","custom_content_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":16,"sizes":[]},"custom_content_typography_font_weight":"400","toggle_button_color":"#00A8E0","toggle_button_typography_typography":"custom","toggle_button_typography_font_family":"Montserrat","toggle_button_typography_font_weight":"600","toggle_button_hover_color":"#2F4F4F","toggle_button_align":"left","toggle_button_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":16,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"htmega-toggle-addons"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Support
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Support

When the time is tough, it is OK to ask for help

Victoria State Emergency Service

Flood information for the East Gippsland Shire Council, including a local flood guide for Lakes Entrance, Eagle Point, Metung, Paynesville and Raymond Island as well as the East Gippsland Shire Municipal Flood Emergency Plan.

Flood Emergency Service

It developed to assist regional and state flood response agencies monitor floods and predict potential impacts. The results will also feed into SES Victoria’s Flood Safe program to raise awareness, educate and prepare communities for floods.

Bureau of Meteorology

The BOM is Australia’s national weather, climate and water agency. Its services assist Australians in dealing with the harsh realities of their natural environment, including drought, floods, fires, storms.

Agriculture Industry

If you run a business in the agriculture industry you need to know about the relevant legislation, licences and permits, and other business requirements.

Agriculture Victoria

Agriculture Victoria delivers tools, calculators, newsletters, grants, networks, programs and services for farmers and producers.

National Relay Service

Advances in technology have improved the range of accessible services for people who are deaf, hard of hearing and/or have a speech impairment.

Emergency calls for flood

Call 132 500 from anywhere in Victoria for flood, storm, tsunami and earthquake emergency. For life-threatening emergencies call Triple Zero (000).
Current emergency information is available by calling the VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226. At any time, warnings and advice are available by visiting the VicEmergency website.

Name Call Office hours
East Office – Bairnsdale

130 Macleod Street Bairnsdale, Victoria 3875 		Phone: (03) 9256 9400

Email: east@ses.vic.gov.au
9am-5pm, Monday to Friday (excluding public holidays)
East Office – Moe

PO Box 631 82A Moore Street Moe, Victoria 3825 		Phone: (03) 9256 9450

Email: east@ses.vic.gov.au
9am-5pm, Monday to Friday (excluding public holidays)

Farmer support in Gippsland

As outlined in its statement of purpose, Gippsland Emergency Relief Fund “has been established to provide immediate financial assistance to residents who suffer loss or hardship as a result of an emergency that occurs within the Gippsland region”.

The fund is a registered charitable organisation (Registered number A0020241A), making all donations tax-deductible. All donations are returned to the community and no costs are deducted.

Explore more
Name Call
RFCS Gippsland 1300 045 747
www.ruralfinancialcounselling.org.au
Rural Financial Counselling Service Client Care Hub ruralfinancialcounselling.org.au /services/client_care_hub/
Salvation Army

Bairnsdale
Sale


(03) 5152 4201
(03) 5144 6347
Uniting Gippsland

Bairnsdale
Sale

(03) 5152 9600
(03) 5144 5177
Australian Government Farmer Assistance hotline 13 23 16

As outlined in its statement of purpose, Gippsland Emergency Relief Fund “has been established to provide immediate financial assistance to residents who suffer loss or hardship as a result of an emergency that occurs within the Gippsland region”.

The fund is a registered charitable organisation (Registered number A0020241A), making all donations tax-deductible. All donations are returned to the community and no costs are deducted.

item.title: Service
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Are you worried about excessive rainfall for crops ?

Looking for Get Started

Know more about Gippsland

Gippsland is a rural region of Victoria, Australia, located in the south-eastern part of that state.

Gippsland is generally broken down into the East Gippsland, South Gippsland, West Gippsland, and the Latrobe Valley statistical divisions.

Read more

What we offer

Soil information

Weather information

Crop information

Recommendation

Support

About us

The CropSomatic project aims to provide recommendations to young farmers who are planning to start their career in farming.

Know more

DISCLAIMER

While we make effort to ensure that information and material on this site is accurate and up to date (unless denoted as archived materials), such materials and information do in no way constitute the provision of professional advice. CropSomatic does not guarantee, and accepts no legal liability whatsoever arising from or connected to, the accuracy, reliability, currency or completeness of any information and materials contained on this website or any linked sites.

Through this website, you will be able to see the links to the other websites which are not under the control of CropSomatic. We have no control over the nature, content and availability of those sites. The inclusion of any links does not necessarily imply a recommendation or endorse the views expressed within them.

item.title: Page celery
item.dc:creator: user
item.content:encoded:
Celery

  • Overview
  • Growing environment
  • Sowing seed
  • Planting
  • Care
  • Harvesting

Celery is a cool season crop and is best grown in the moderate weather of spring to early summer. It has a reputation of being hard to grow, but when planted in the right conditions, it can thrive in the farm.

Classic mistakes:
Don’t plant celery when the weather is too warm or too cold. The key to success with celery is moderate weather.

Sunlight:
Grow in: Partial Shade - Full Sun

You might be tempted to plant celery in a shady spot because it’s a leafy green. Celery actually needs quite a lot of sun to produce big plants and long stems. It needs at least 5-7 hours of sun a day, but will enjoy some afternoon shade.

Soil preparation:
Dig in lots compost and well-rotted manure. Celery is a heavy feeder and likes rich, well-draining soil. Celery plants have exceptionally fine roots, so they need very light soil. If you have heavier soil in your garden, then you can plant them into pure compost in a raised bed.

You might be tempted to plant celery in a shady environment because it’s a leafy green. Celery actually needs quite a lot of sun to produce big plants and long stems. It needs at least 5-7 hours of sun a day, but will enjoy some afternoon shade.

Dig in lots compost and well-rotted manure. Celery is a heavy feeder and likes rich, well-draining soil. Celery plants have exceptionally fine roots, so they need very light soil. If you have heavier soil in your field, then you can plant them into pure compost in a raised bed.

Sow seed: September-OctoberSowing depth: Simply sprinkle the seeds onto your soil, cover loosely, and water in. 

Soak the seeds for 24 hours before planting.

Simply sprinkle the seeds onto your soil, cover loosely, and water in. Celery is quite tricky to grow from seed, so unless you’re a very experienced gardener, rather plant seedlings. Celery seeds are really tiny, which makes them hard to sow evenly. Like carrots, they need to be thinned once they’re up. The easiest way to thin them is to use a small pair of scissors and simply cut away the unwanted seedlings. Cutting is a great way to remove any extra seedlings without disturbing the ones you plan to keep.

Plant seedlings: November-December 

Plant celery in trenches and gradually full the trenches as the celery grows, this helps to blanch the stems and makes them tastier when eaten raw. Celery doesn’t like to be crowded, so make sure there is only one plant per hole. Sometimes even bought seedling may contain more than one plant per pot. If this is the case, either separate them and plant both or thin the weaker plant. Celery can also be grown from discarded celery roots. Simply buy celery that still has its roots on, use the stalks, and re-root the roots; either in soil or water.

Once the stalks reach a good size, tie them loosely and then wrap them in newspaper. Allow the leaves to sick out the top. You can harvest them 2-3 weeks later. The newspaper will protect them from the sun, and they should be pale when you harvest them.

Watering:
Water regularly to keep the soil moist. Celery likes moist soil, so don’t let it dry out. Remember to give your plants extra water during hot, dry weather.

Feeding:
Celery is a very heavy feeder. Give your plants a good, nitrogen-rich feed every few weeks. Manure, compost tea or organic fertiliser are all good options.

Mulching:
Mulch your celery plants with a thick layer of organic mulch. This will help to keep their roots cool and moist. Lucerne, sugarcane and pea-straw are all good options.

Harvest: 11 to 18 Weeks After Planting

Celery can be harvested whole or you may remove one stalk at a time as needed. Simply pull the tops of the stalks down towards the soil to snap them off the plant or cut them at the base as you would for spinach.
